Lets talk about Networks in Biology in this thread!!

In our recent paper Graphs with polarities, @John Baez and I studied how monoid labeled directed graphs can model regulatory networks in biology when the monoid is suitably chosen. We discussed the work related to this paper here #theory: applied category theory > Graphs with polarities . Now I am trying to understand the content of this interesting paper Cell Fate Reprogramming by Control of Intracellular Network Dynamics by Jorge G. T. Zañudo and Réka Albert (Suggested by @John Baez ). Let me start by spelling out my very initial understanding of the paper. I apologise priorly if my understanding sounds very naive and immature at the moment. I expect to get better with my understanding in the coming days. In this thread, I am assunming the notations used in our paper Graphs with polarities.

How the framework in the paper Cell Fate Reprogramming by Control of Intracellular Network Dynamics relates to our framework in Graphs with polarities??

For a monoid MMM, let (G,ℓ ⁣:E→M)(G, \ell \colon E \to M)(G,ℓ:E→M) be a monoid labeled graph. Although in Graphs with polarities, we modelled regulatory network as a MMM-labeled graph for some suitable choices of monoids MMM, we have not studied the dynamics of MMM-labeled graphs. I feel Biologists are usually interested in three kinds of dynamics:

  • Quantitative dynamics (For example, @Evan Patterson et al studied an O.D.E based dynamics of regulatory networks via structured cospan formalism here) .
  • Logic based dynamics (Eg: Boolean networks)
  • Hybrid dynamics (which is a hybrid of both quantitative dynamics and logic based dynamics ).

For a detailed discussion related to "how the above three classes of dynamics modelling approach differ and how each has its own advantages", please see the paper Quantitative and logic modelling of gene and molecular networks by Nicolas Le Novère.

I feel the paper Cell Fate Reprogramming by Control of Intracellular Network Dynamics discusses certain interesting and as well as useful aspects of logic based dynamics of our Z/2\mathbb{Z}/2Z/2-labeled graphs in Graphs with polarities and is discussed in terms of Boolean networks. In particular, the authors studied how stabilizing the expression or activity of a few select nodes of a regulatory network can drive the cell towards a desired fate or away from an undesired fate. I may be wrong but next, I will try to argue why I think a Boolean network describe a logic based dynamics of our MMM-labeled graphs!!.

Below, I am trying to write my understanding of a Boolean model of the discrete dynamics of a regulatory network as explained in An effective network reduction approach to find the dynamical repertoire of discrete dynamic networks adopted in the framework of monoid labeled graphs.

Consider a MMM-labeled graph (G=(E,V,s,t),ℓ ⁣:E→M)(G=(E,V,s,t), \ell \colon E \to M)(G=(E,V,s,t),ℓ:E→M). Let V={v1,v2,⋯ ,vn}V= \lbrace v_1, v_2, \cdots, v_{n} \rbraceV={v1​,v2​,⋯,vn​}. Now, suppose for each i=1,2,⋯ni =1, 2, \cdots ni=1,2,⋯n, consider a {0,1}\lbrace 0,1 \rbrace{0,1}-valued function fi ⁣:N→{0,1}f_i \colon \mathbb{N} \to \lbrace 0, 1 \rbracefi​:N→{0,1} the state function of the vertex viv_ivi​. We define the state of the vertex viv_ivi​ at time ttt as fi(t)f_{i}(t)fi​(t).

If fi(t)=0f_i(t)=0fi​(t)=0, we will say the vertex viv_ivi​ is off.

If fi(t)=1f_i(t)=1fi​(t)=1, we will say the vertex viv_ivi​ is on.

We define the tuple F(t)=(f1(t),f2(t),⋯ ,fn(t))F(t)=(f_1(t), f_2(t), \cdots, f_{n}(t))F(t)=(f1​(t),f2​(t),⋯,fn​(t)) as the state of (G,ℓ)(G, \ell)(G,ℓ) at time ttt.

Now for each iii, we have to equip an updating function

fi(t+1)=ϕi(∏t(ej)=vi,s(ej)=vj((fj(t),ℓ(ej)))f_i(t+1)= \phi_i \bigg( \prod_{t(e_j)=v_i, s(e_j)=v_j} \big( (f_j(t), \ell(e_j) \big) \bigg)fi​(t+1)=ϕi​(∏t(ej​)=vi​,s(ej​)=vj​​((fj​(t),ℓ(ej​))), where

ϕi ⁣:({0,1}×M)∣G(−,vi)∣→{0,1}\phi_i \colon (\lbrace 0,1 \rbrace \times M)^{|{G(-, v_i)}|} \to \lbrace 0,1 \rbrace ϕi​:({0,1}×M)∣G(−,vi​)∣→{0,1}, where G(−,vi)={e ⁣:t(e)=vi}G(-, v_i) = \lbrace e \colon t(e)=v_i \rbraceG(−,vi​)={e:t(e)=vi​}.

Thus, we can extend the above definition to an updating family of functions

ϕ=(ϕ1,ϕ2,⋯ ,ϕn) \phi=(\phi_1, \phi_2, \cdots, \phi_n )ϕ=(ϕ1​,ϕ2​,⋯,ϕn​) which updates the state of (G,ℓ)(G, \ell)(G,ℓ) from F(t)F(t)F(t) to F(t+1)F(t+1)F(t+1).

Thus, I am defining a Boolean model of the discrete dynamics of (G,ℓ)(G, \ell)(G,ℓ) as the tuple ((G,ℓ),ϕ)((G, \ell), \phi)((G,ℓ),ϕ), with a given initial state F(0)=(f1(0),f2(0),⋯fn(0))F(0)=(f_1(0), f_2(0), \cdots f_n(0))F(0)=(f1​(0),f2​(0),⋯fn​(0)) at t=0t=0t=0.

Above is an example of synchronous updating scheme, where the state of every vertex is updated simultaneously. However, in many cases, the updating scheme is asynchronous, in which we have to define the updating function accordingly. (I have to think how to talk about it in a formal way).

Next I want to understand the concept of attractor, a set of states in which the above dynamics eventually settles down. According to the authors in Cell Fate Reprogramming by Control of Intracellular Network Dynamics,

"The attractors of intracellular networks have been found to be identifiable with different cell fates, cell behaviors, and stable patterns of cell activity"

It might be good to start by focusing on the synchronous updating scheme for boolean networks, even though it's oversimplified, and look at various biologically interesting behaviors that can naturally arise from this scheme. The paper you're writing about claims to make progress in this:

As it was pointed out in section II A, the state space of
a Boolean network with N nodes contains 2N2^N2N states. This
exponential dependence on the number of nodes of the
state space's size makes the problem of finding the attractors
of a Boolean network computationally intractable,
which means a full search of the state space can be performed,
in practice, only for small networks.

To overcome this challenge several types of methods have
been proposed to simplify the search space. The most
prominent of these approaches, the so-called network reduction
methods [35-38], shrink the effective network size
by removing frozen nodes (nodes that reach the same
steady state regardless of initial conditions) [38-40] and
dynamically irrelevant nodes (such as simple mediator
nodes or nodes with no outputs), and by simplifying the
Boolean functions (for example, due to the presence of a
node with a fixed state), thus reducing the effective state
space.

Although the reduction methods developed so far have
been successfully applied to several biological networks
[35-37, 41], they have some limitations [....]

The method that we propose is based on the idea that
certain components of the network can only stabilize in
one or a small number of attractors. This idea is itself
not new and is closely related to R. Thomas' rules
linking feedback loops with the appearance of complex
dynamical behavior in biological networks [19]. For example,
an approach that connects the dynamics of certain
network motifs to construct the attractors of the full
Boolean network was recently proposed by Siebert [28].
The novelty of our method is the efficiency of identifying
every motif that stabilizes in an asynchronous attractor
despite being coupled to the rest of the network...

This makes me want to figure out what their method is. I couldn't succeed in a few minutes of work. I don't even know what it means to say a motif stabilizes in an "asynchronous attractor", given that they're studying the synchronous updating scheme. But it would definitely be worth spending an hour or two trying to figure out their method! If it's too hard, maybe some of the papers they refer to are easier.

By the way, here is a free version of the paper you linked to, on the arXiv:

  • An effective network reduction approach to find the dynamical repertoire of discrete dynamic networks.

The version you pointed to doesn't seem to be open-source.

1) State of the neighbours of vvv at ttt (state of neighbours also include the state of vvv itself at ttt).

2) Regulatory nature (stimulation, inhibition, etc.) of the neighbours of vvv on vvv.

Kevin Carlson said:

I bounced off the complicated notation for your updating function at first glance. Maybe you can just say what you mean in words too? There's a graph floating around here and yet nobody said anything like "the state depend son the state of all the neighbors"!

Adittya mentioned a graph, but I don't see why. Maybe the paper talks about a graph? I prefer to think about a boolean network: a set of vertices and for each vertex vvv a set SvS_vSv​ of vertices together with a boolean function BSv→B\mathbb{B}^{S_v} \to \mathbb{B} BSv​→B telling us the state of that vertex as a function of the states of the vertices in SvS_vSv​. If we start by assigning each vertex a boolean at time ttt, we can update the state at time t+1t+1t+1 using these functions in the hopefully obvious way.

At least this is my impression of how boolean networks work. Wikipedia puts it this way:

A Boolean network consists of a discrete set of Boolean variables each of which has a Boolean function (possibly different for each variable) assigned to it which takes inputs from a subset of those variables and output that determines the state of the variable it is assigned to. This set of functions in effect determines a topology (connectivity) on the set of variables, which then become nodes in a network. Usually, the dynamics of the system is taken as a discrete time series where the state of the entire network at time t+1 is determined by evaluating each variable's function on the state of the network at time t.

I am trying to write down my current understanding of stable motifs in a Boolean network as discussed in An effective network reduction approach to find the dynamical repertoire of discrete dynamic networks.

Sorry I realised I was misunderstanding very fundamentally about Boolean networks. In particular, I realised that the graph structure in Boolean network is induced from the Boolean functions on the nodes. Before, I was misunderstanding by thinking that "we are starting with a graph structure and then adding the Boolean functions to it". I now realised what @John Baez explained here #theory: applied category theory > Networks in Biology @ 💬 . So, I decided to delete my yesterday night's post and redfine the notions according to my current realisations.

Boolean network:
A Boolean network BBB consists of a finite set of nodes V={v1,v2,⋯vn}V= \lbrace v_1, v_2, \cdots v_{n} \rbraceV={v1​,v2​,⋯vn​} along with

  • a family of subsets {Svi⊆V}i=1,2,⋯ ,n\lbrace S_{v_i} \subseteq V \rbrace_{i=1,2, \cdots, n}{Svi​​⊆V}i=1,2,⋯,n​ whose members are the regulators of viv_ivi​,
  • a family of functions {fi ⁣:BSvi→B}i=1,2,⋯ ,n \lbrace f_{i} \colon \mathbb{B}^{S_{v_i}} \to \mathbb{B} \rbrace_{i=1,2, \cdots, n}{fi​:BSvi​​→B}i=1,2,⋯,n​ whose members are the Boolean functions associated to viv_ivi​.

Graph associated to a Boolean network:
Let B=(vi,Svi,fi)i=1,2,⋯nB=(v_i, S_{v_i}, f_i)_{i= 1,2, \cdots n}B=(vi​,Svi​​,fi​)i=1,2,⋯n​ be a Boolean network. We define a graph GB=(E,V,s,t)G_{B}=(E,V, s, t)GB​=(E,V,s,t) whose

  • set of vertices VVV is the set of nodes in BBB
  • the set of edges E:={(v,vi) ⁣:v∈Svi,i∈{1,2,⋯ ,n}}E:= \lbrace \big(v, v_i\big) \colon v \in S_{v_{i}}, i \in \lbrace 1,2, \cdots, n \rbrace\rbrace E:={(v,vi​):v∈Svi​​,i∈{1,2,⋯,n}}
  • the source s ⁣:E→V,(v,vi)↦v s \colon E \to V, (v,v_i) \mapsto vs:E→V,(v,vi​)↦v,
  • the target t ⁣:E→V,(v,vi)↦vit \colon E \to V, (v, v_i) \mapsto v_it:E→V,(v,vi​)↦vi​.
    We define the graph GBG_{B}GB​ as the graph associated to Boolean network BBB.

Remark:
Note that GBG_{B}GB​ does not permit multiple edges between vertices.

Discrete dynamics of a Boolean network:
Let B=(vi,Svi,fi)i=1,2,⋯nB=(v_i, S_{v_i}, f_i)_{i= 1,2, \cdots n}B=(vi​,Svi​​,fi​)i=1,2,⋯n​ be a Boolean network. Consider a family of functions {ϕi ⁣:N→BSvi}i=1,2,⋯n \lbrace \phi_i \colon \mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{B}^{S_{v_i}} \rbrace_{i=1, 2, \cdots n}{ϕi​:N→BSvi​​}i=1,2,⋯n​, whose members are called the updating functions of the node viv_ivi​. We define the discrete dynamics of BBB as the the n-tuple FB=(f1∘ϕ1,f2∘ϕ2,⋯ ,fn∘ϕn)F_{B}= \big( f_1 \circ \phi_1, f_2 \circ \phi_2, \cdots ,f_n \circ \phi_{n} \big)FB​=(f1​∘ϕ1​,f2​∘ϕ2​,⋯,fn​∘ϕn​).

State of the Boolean dynamics:

Let (B,FB)(B, F_{B})(B,FB​) be the discrete dynamics of the Boolean network B=(vi,Svi,fi)i=1,2,⋯nB=(v_i, S_{v_i}, f_i)_{i= 1,2, \cdots n}B=(vi​,Svi​​,fi​)i=1,2,⋯n​. We define the state of (B,FB)(B, F_{B})(B,FB​) at time t∈Nt \in \mathbb{N}t∈N as the n-tuple

F(t):=(f1∘ϕ1(t),f2∘ϕ2(t),⋯ ,fn∘ϕn(t))∈BnF(t):= \big( f_1 \circ \phi_1(t), f_2 \circ \phi_2(t), \cdots ,f_n \circ \phi_{n}(t) \big) \in \mathbb{B}^{n}F(t):=(f1​∘ϕ1​(t),f2​∘ϕ2​(t),⋯,fn​∘ϕn​(t))∈Bn,

and we define the state of the vertex viv_ivi​ at time t∈Nt \in \mathbb{N}t∈N as the projection of F(t)F(t)F(t) to its ithi_{th}ith​ coordinate.

Based on the above formalisms, I will define the notion of stable motifs later today.

There is something slightly strange about that definition, because it could be that one of the functions fif_ifi​ doesn't depend on one of its arguments, say j∈Svij\in S_{v_i}j∈Svi​​. Then the graph will have an edge from jjj to iii even though there is no influence of jjj on iii, if that makes sense. I'm not sure if this will matter for anything or not.

Maybe a better way to express that is: what's the right notion of morphism for Boolean networks? It seems like maybe you'd want such a network to be isomorphic to one where j∉Svij\not\in S_{v_i}j∈Svi​​.

I have thought about Nathaniel's point when I was defining "stock flow diagrams", which have "links" pointing from "stocks" to "flows" together with a function saying how a flow depends on those stocks that have links pointing to it. The function could be independent of one of its arguments! Then one link would be unnecessary. But instead of trying to forbid this, I decided it was better to allow it.

To disallow it is a bit like trying to say a constant function is not really a function. "What? You're telling me 3 is a function of x? That's absurd!" It feels convincing in a certain gut-level way, but I think it's mathematically very inconvenient.

Thanks!!

I think Biologists often prefer to work with the following labeled version of graphs associated to Boolean networks:

Labeled Boolean graph:
Let GBG_{B}GB​ be the graph associated to a Boolean network B=(vi,Svi,fi)i=1,2,⋯ ,nB=(v_i, S_{v_i}, f_{i})_{i=1,2, \cdots ,n}B=(vi​,Svi​​,fi​)i=1,2,⋯,n​. For a monoid MMM, we define a MMM-labeled Boolean graph of BBB as a MMM-labeled graph (as defined in our paper Graphs with polarities) (GB ⁣:ℓ ⁣:E→M)(G_{B} \colon \ell \colon E \to M)(GB​:ℓ:E→M).

Remark:
Note that in the diagram attached, authors considered a Z/2\mathbb{Z}/2Z/2-labeled Boolean graph of some Boolean network BBB.

Now, I propose a solution to the issue raised by @Nathaniel Virgo as follows:

Let us work in the Z/3\mathbb{Z}/3Z/3-labeled Boolean graph whose one of the element say 000 represents "no-influece" [We discussed this in Example 3.4 in our paper Graphs with polarities].

Then, I would like to label the unnecessary edges with the element 000 ??

By the way, I think this issue is distracting from the more urgent goal of figuring out what "reduction approach" is being explained in An effective network reduction approach to find the dynamical repertoire of discrete dynamic networks.

Our earlier paper was setting up a formalism, and for that it's nice to pay careful attention to details. But if one is trying to understand a biology paper one needs to start by trying to understand the main thing they're trying to say, and later worry about details.
(sorry, I didn't mean to distract, the detail just popped out at me when I read the post!)
No problem - I'm just trying to act like Adittya's advisor, since he doesn't seem to mind that, and I'm trying to push him into doing actual biology, since he seems to want that.

Thanks very much!! I am very glad and grateful for this!!

It would be interesting to look at commonalities and differences of approach in this field. In a paper along the lines of that Symmetries of Living Systems book I mentioned elsewhere,

  • Luis A. Álvarez-García, Wolfram Liebermeister, Ian Leifer, Hernán A. Makse, Complexity reduction by symmetry: uncovering the minimal regulatory network for logical computation in bacteria,

the authors explain the steps of their work to understand something as complex as E. coli

image.png

The use of fibrations should make people here feel very at home.
What's a 'TRN'? I'm assuming a 'GRN' is a gene regulatory network.

Hmm, looking at the paper I don't see them defining 'TRN', but nor do I see them using that term except in the one section header that David gave us a screenshot of! So never mind.

There is a lot of interesting stuff in this paper. I see what seems like the bold claim that most of the gene regulatory network of E. coli (for example) is unnecessary to understand the behavior of this bacterium, or at least the most important aspects.

They start with a gene regulatory network (GRN) with 4692 genes and then trim it down to a 'minimal' GRN with just 42 genes. I don't yet understand the algorithm they use, and I also don't know what properties are supposed to be preserved by this massive simplification. But it sounds remarkable. I guess how remarkable it is depends on how much evolution penalizes inefficiency.

It could be that some seemingly unimportant aspects of the bacteria's GRN become important under some special conditions.

I'm glad to see the key idea of 'fibration' for these GRNs seems to be taken from my friend Eugene Lerman and a collaborator: I remember Eugene working on it and it's nice to see someone has picked up on it!

Here's an interesting passage:

We have shown before [4, 10, 11, 24] that the use of fibrations allows for the breakdown of the network into its fundamental synchronized building blocks, the fiber building blocks. Each fiber belongs to a fiber building block, defined as the induced subgraph formed from the nodes in the fiber, and the nodes that send inputs to the fiber (the regulators).

[....]

We find that these fiber building blocks can be precisely characterized by just two numbers n (or φ) and ℓ, defining the |n, ℓ⟩ classes [10].

Paper [10] is

  • Flaviano Morone, Ian Leifer, and Hernán A Makse, Fibration symmetries uncover the building blocks of biological networks, Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences 117(15) (2020), 8306–8314.

This passage in the paper makes my crackpot alarm ring:

The building blocks are classified into topological classes of input trees characterized by integer branching ratios and fractal golden ratios of Fibonacci sequences representing cycles of information.

Anyone who mentions 'fractal', 'golden ratio' and 'Fibonacci' in the same sentence makes me afraid.

On a different note (but might be related), for last few days (after @David Corfield shared the paper on symmetries of Living systems), I was trying to understand the Math of Graph fibrations from the paper fibrations of graphs by Boldi and Vigna.

Last to last week, one of my collegue at my current institute (ISI, Kolkata, Stat-Math Dept.) gave a talk on discrete AAA-homotopy of undirected simple graphs, where he was also talking about "local isomorphism" properties imply casrtesian morphisms lifting in graph fibrations. Although his definition of graph is a bit restrictive than ours. Interestingly, I find the notion of local isomorphisms present in the "paper on graph fibrations" (for eg: Please see page 25 of Fibration of graphs) relatable.

Now again, I am continuing from here #theory: applied category theory > Networks in Biology @ 💬 towards network reduction methods discussed in An effective network reduction approach to find the dynamical repertoire of discrete dynamic networks

Expanded network of a Boolean network:

Let B=(vi,Svi,fvi)i=1,2,⋯nB=(v_i, S_{v_i}, f_{v_i})_{i= 1,2, \cdots n}B=(vi​,Svi​​,fvi​​)i=1,2,⋯n​ be a Boolean network. Then, the expanded network of a Boolean network BBB is the graph GExp(B)G_{Exp(B)}GExp(B)​ of a Boolean network Exp(B)Exp(B)Exp(B) obtained from GBG_BGB​ via the following two operations:

  • 1) For every node viv_{i}vi​ we introduce a complementary node viˉ\bar{v_i}vi​ˉ​ such that the Boolean function associated to viˉ\bar{v_i}vi​ˉ​ is the negation of the Boolean function fi ⁣:BSvi→B f_{i} \colon \mathbb{B}^{S_{v_i}} \to \mathbb{B} fi​:BSvi​​→B associated to viv_ivi​.
  • 2) Let {vi1,vi2,…,vik}\lbrace v_{i1}, v_{i2}, \ldots, v_{ik} \rbrace{vi1​,vi2​,…,vik​} denote the elements of Svi⊆VS_{v_i} \subseteq VSvi​​⊆V, and let fif_ifi​ is expressed in the following form
    synergistic.png

where sjs_jsj​'s are either the states of one of the kkk elements of SviS_{v_i}Svi​​ or one of these states' negations. In the same way, one can also represent the negation of the update function fiˉ\bar{f_i}fi​ˉ​ in a similar form. Then, composite nodes (v1v2⋯vk),(vk+1vk+2⋯vl),…(v_1v_2 \cdots v_{k}), (v_{k+1} v_{k+2} \cdots v_{l}), \ldots(v1​v2​⋯vk​),(vk+1​vk+2​⋯vl​),… so on... are added for every set of nodes involved in a conjunctive clause (AND-dependent relationship) and for every constituent node of the composite node an edge is drawn from the constituent node to the composite node. A simpler example of this operation is attached in the screenshot.

examplesyn.png

Stable motifs are certain strongly connected components of GExp(B)G_{Exp(B)}GExp(B)​, which I am going to define next!!
Before defining stable motifs, I will say a few things about "what Exp(B)Exp(B)Exp(B) gives us"!!

Okay, so Z\mathbb{Z}Z is time. But I don't think "time" should be part of the definition of a boolean network. Time, and in particular integer-valued-time, is part of one possible semantics for boolean networks.

I wanted to express the fact that the function fif_ifi​ tells that the (t+1)th(t+1)_{th}(t+1)th​ state of the vertex viv_ivi​ is determined by the ttht_{th}tth​ states of the vertices of the neighbours of viv_ivi​. If you're trying to compute the next state as a function of the current state, you just need to describe a function that maps states to states. You don't need to mention time at all. (And you definitely don't need to subtract 1, since subtracting one takes us one time step into the past, not the future!)

As I've said before, I think a boolean network is

1) a finite set VVV of nodes,
2) a set SvS_vSv​ of nodes for each node vvv, and
3) a function ϕv:BSv→B\phi_v : \mathbb{B}^{S_v} \to \mathbb{B}ϕv​:BSv​→B for each node vvv.

That's all.

A state of a boolean network is a function

s:V→B s: V \to \mathbb{B}s:V→B

From a boolean network it's easy to define a time evolution function

F:BV→BV F: \mathbb{B}^V \to \mathbb{B}^VF:BV→BV

that maps states to states. (I'll leave this as an exercise: here we use the functions ϕv\phi_vϕv​.)

Thus, if we have a state sss, we get a sequence of states F(s),F(F(s)),…F(s), F(F(s)), \dots F(s),F(F(s)),… which describe how the state evolves in time, and we can define the state at time n∈Nn \in \mathbb{N}n∈N to be Fn(s)F^n(s)Fn(s).

This seems much simpler than bringing in the mysterious functions and ψi\psi_iψi​, and all this stuff about integers, including the function T1:N→ZT_1 : \mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{Z}T1​:N→Z.

Also - this is a smaller stylistic point - there's no need to index the vertices by numbers i=1,…,ni = 1, \dots, ni=1,…,n. Indexing by numbers is often a mistake. You can use the vertices to name themselves! For example when you write "the vertex viv_ivi​" you can just write "the vertex vvv", and when you write SviS_{v_i}Svi​​ you can just write SvS_vSv​, and when you write ϕi\phi_iϕi​ you can write ϕv\phi_vϕv​. That simplifies some expressions, and it avoids bringing in these irrelevant numbers i=1,…,n i = 1, \dots, ni=1,…,n, which just distract us from the actual ideas.

By a discrete possibilistic dynamical system I mean a set SSS together with a map TTT from SSS to its power set P(S)P(S)P(S), which describes how each state (= element of SSS) can evolve to any state in the subset T({s})T(\{s\})T({s}).

Of course 'discrete possibilistic dynamical system' is just a silly name for a relation from a set to itself. But there's a nice analogy between probability theory and possibility theory, which this term is supposed to evoke. In probability theory we assign a number between 0 and 1 to each event, which tells us how probable that event is. In possibility theory we just assign either 0 or 1 to each event, which tells us whether that event is possible.
If we replace the power set monad by the Giry monad, we get a discrete probabilistic dynamical system, where each state evolves to a probability distribution on states.
I guess people usually say 'stochastic' instead of 'probabilistic' here, and similarly they say 'nondeterministic' instead of 'possibilistic'.

A Kleisli morphism can send an edge of GGG to a formal composite of edges of HHH. Kleisli morphisms are no good if one is considering each edge as taking one time step to traverse, as they sometimes seem to be thinking (e.g. when they're thinking of gene regulatory networks as synchronized processes.) But they're fine if one is not worried about time steps. Then you could say a Kleisli morphism between graphs is a fibration iff F:G∗→H∗F : G^\ast \to H^\astF:G∗→H∗ is a fibration - i.e., it's a fibration iff its a fibration.

Regarding the issue of symmetry, I recall making considerable use of that Alan Weinstein paper Groupoids: unifying internal and external symmetry for my paper on groupoids, later Ch. 9 of my 2003 book. He considered there "local symmetries" of a tiled floor, so that there are several different kinds of point: outside corners, outside edge points, inside edge points, internal intersections, etc.

I think things are similar here in that one looks for local symmetries between nodes, though perhaps one further step is taken in that we're looking to relate nodes only in terms of isomorphic input trees. The activity of a node only depends on messages sent to it, not on what it sends.

The big book's preferences are to convey this "symmetry" they're interested in via graph fibrations, that we've discussed, and via balanced colorings. A network is colored by coloring its nodes. The coloring is balanced if any two nodes of the same color receive inputs from neighbors with the same colors.

And this is generalised to typed networks, e.g., repressors and activators,

Nodes of the same color have inputs that match each other, as regards both the type of edge and the color of the source of that edge. That is, nodes of the same colors ‘receive’ the same colors from in-neighbors. (p. 17)

Balanced colorings and fibrations are equivalent -- they're recording isomorphisms between the whole input tree, not just the one-step input set. So more work needs to be done in the case of the network groupoid, since this is defined solely in terms of the input sets. In addition, one looks for coloring subgroupoids

Many results about balanced colorings can be interpreted using coloring subgroupoids,
but the theory is technical. See (Stewart, 2024). (p. 122)

They seem to be suggesting that there's little to gain from the groupoid approach as it requires conditions on subgroupoids that are imitating the definition of a balanced coloring:

image.png

Intriguing the explanation for the relevance of fibrations for biology in that a common evolutionary mechanism is gene duplication. This corresponds (in many cases) to a preservation of the dynamics as maintained by the same fibrational symmetry, but then allowing later symmetry-breaking as different regulators input the two copies. They show how this process leads to "computational" structures, such as memory and clocks.

Now, when the underlying graph morphism of ϕ ⁣:(G,P)→(G′,P′)\phi \colon (G, \mathcal{P}) \to (G', \mathcal{P}') ϕ:(G,P)→(G′,P′) is a fibration of graphs, then the map Pϕ ⁣:P(G′)→P(G)\mathcal{P}\phi \colon \mathcal{P}(G') \to \mathcal{P}(G) Pϕ:P(G′)→P(G) gives a map between the corresponding dynamical systems (interms of certain vector fields on the total phase spaces) (Main therem of the DeVille-Lerman's paper: Theorem 4.3.1). Interestingly, when the underlying graph morphism of ϕ ⁣:(G,P)→(B,P′)\phi \colon (G, \mathcal{P}) \to (B, \mathcal{P}') ϕ:(G,P)→(B,P′) is in particular, surjective fibration of graphs, the map Pϕ ⁣:P(B)→P(G)\mathcal{P}\phi \colon \mathcal{P}(B) \to \mathcal{P}(G) Pϕ:P(B)→P(G) is an embedding of smooth manifolds, which also ensures that the dynamical system of the reduced graph BBB is same as the dynamical system of the original graph GGG (Lemma 5.1.1 in the DeVille and Lerman's paper). Now, this theory makes sense in the framework of Complexity reduction by symmetry: uncovering the minimal regulatory network for logical computation in bacteria as shown in the page 5 (C) of this paper. In particular, authors chose the phase space of the transcriptional regulatory network as R\mathbb{R}R for each node, which represents the expression of genes (represented by vertices) at a time.

Thus, I am convinced that by Step 1 we can legitimately reduce a graph GGG to a graph BBB via a surjective fibration which preserves the dynamical systems, as claimed by the authors:
complexityreductiondynamics.png

  • Since ϕ ⁣:G→B\phi \colon G \to Bϕ:G→B is minmal fibration, it ensures even if we apply more and more surjective fibrations ψ\psiψ to BBB, we can not redcuce it further because BBB is fibration prime.

Hi!! I am writing down some of the things that I was thinking today:

As I explained here #theory: applied category theory > Networks in Biology @ 💬 , I am convinved that if we have a graph GGG, then a reasonable way to reduce the complexity of GGG (preseriving the dynamics of the G) is to collapse the graph GGG to a graph BBB by a minimal fibration ϕ ⁣:G→B\phi \colon G \to Bϕ:G→B. Recall, by definition of a minimal fibration, ϕ\phiϕ is surjective and every surjective fibration ψ ⁣:B→B′\psi \colon B \to B'ψ:B→B′ is an isomorphism. Although there are some ways (for example, Theorem 26 or section 4.1 of "Fibration of Graphs" paper by Boldi-Vigna ), which gives prescription of the required minimal fibration for the reduction of GGG. I was wondering about a particular way of doing the same, in particular, by a suitable action of a group AAA on the graph GGG.

Let me explain!!

Consider a graph GGG and group AAA. Then according to the Section 2.3 of "Fibration of Graphs" paper by Boldi-Vigna, a left action of AAA on GGG is defined as a group homomoprhism ρ ⁣:A→Aut(G)\rho \colon A \to {\rm{Aut}}(G)ρ:A→Aut(G). Now, if y=x⋅ay=x \cdot ay=x⋅a for some a∈Aa \in Aa∈A, then, the action of aaa gives a bijection between G(−,x)≅G(−,y)G(-,x) \cong G(-,y)G(−,x)≅G(−,y). Hence, the equivalence relation induced by the action ρ\rhoρ of AAA on the the vertex set VVV satifies the Local In-isomorphism property image-3.png

Hence, by the Theorem 2 (2) Page 25 of "Fibration of Graphs" paper by Boldi-Vigna, we have a surjective fibration ϕA,ρ ⁣:G→BA\phi_{A, \rho} \colon G \to B_{A}ϕA,ρ​:G→BA​, whose fibres are the orbits of ρ\rhoρ. The vertices of the graph BAB_{A}BA​ are the orbits of ρ\rhoρ and edges from an orbit ϕA,ρ−1(x)\phi_{A, \rho}^{-1}(x)ϕA,ρ−1​(x) to a orbit ϕA,ρ−1(y)\phi_{A, \rho}^{-1}(y)ϕA,ρ−1​(y) are the edges coming to an element of ϕ−1(y)\phi^{-1}(y)ϕ−1(y) from all the elements of ϕA,ρ−1(x)\phi_{A, \rho}^{-1}(x)ϕA,ρ−1​(x).

Questions:

  • 1) Is ϕ ⁣:G→BA\phi \colon G \to B_{A}ϕ:G→BA​ always a minimal fibration ? (I feel it is not true)
  • 2) Given a graph GGG, can we always find a group AAA and an action ρ\rhoρ of AAA on GGG such that ϕA,ρ ⁣:G→BA\phi_{A, \rho} \colon G \to B_{A}ϕA,ρ​:G→BA​ is a minimal fibration ?

Answers to above questions may give us some relationships between reduction of complexities of a graph via action of certain groups on the graph.

On a different note, I am not very happy with the definition of a left action of a group on the graph as given in the Section 2.3 of "Fibration of Graphs" paper by Boldi-Vigna.

Let me argue why I think so:

Recall, a morphism of graphs ϕ ⁣:G→H\phi \colon G \to Hϕ:G→H is called a fibration if Free(ϕ) ⁣:Free(G)→Free(H)\mathsf{Free}(\phi) \colon \mathsf{Free}(G) \to \mathsf{Free}(H)Free(ϕ):Free(G)→Free(H) is a discrete fibration.

In the light of the above definition of fibration of graph, it is natural for me to see how an action ρ ⁣:A→Aut(G)\rho \colon A \to \rm{Aut}(G)ρ:A→Aut(G) of a group AAA on the graph GGG induces an action on the category Free(G)\mathsf{Free}(G)Free(G). I think, the action is not that interesting because, it induces canonically a strict action of the discrete 2-group [A⇉A][A \rightrightarrows A][A⇉A] on Free(G)\mathsf{Free}(G)Free(G). Thus, I would prefer a higher analog:

Definition:
Let GGG be a graph and A=[A1⇉A0]\mathbb{A}=[A_1 \rightrightarrows A_0]A=[A1​⇉A0​] be a strict 2-group. Then a left action of AAA on GGG is defined as a functor ρ ⁣:A×Free(G)→Free(G)\rho \colon \mathbb{A} \times \mathsf{Free}(G) \to \mathsf{Free}(G)ρ:A×Free(G)→Free(G) such that

  • ρ0 ⁣:A0×V→V\rho_0 \colon A_0 \times V \to Vρ0​:A0​×V→V and
  • ρ1 ⁣:A1×Mor(Free(G))→Mor(Free(G))\rho_1 \colon A_1 \times \rm{Mor}(\mathsf{Free}(G)) \to \rm{Mor}(\mathsf{Free}(G))ρ1​:A1​×Mor(Free(G))→Mor(Free(G))
    are group actions of A0A_0A0​ and A1A_1A1​ respectively.

Note that the above is a standard definition of an action of a strict 2-group on a category, whose smooth analog are standard in the 2-group gauge theory literature.

I am not sure but it might be interesting to investigate (at least Mathematically), what kind of discrete fibrations over "suitable quotient categories" these higher actions may produce, and under what conditions it give a suitable notion of minimal discrete fibrations.

I don't know if it will help, but just a word about synchronization.

In the distributed computing literature, "synchronization" is usually expressed in terms of a scheduler. Intuitively, the scheduler specifies how events occur in a system: e.g., all processes proceed simultaneously, or only one at a time, or else. There are many ways to formalize this, but the easiest I know is as a set of (legal) executions.

Let S(G)S(G)S(G) be the set of legal executions on a network GGG for the scheduler SSS. In the presence of a fibration G→HG \to HG→H, we can, quite often, lift legal executions on HHH to legal executions on GGG, i.e. we have a map S(H)→S(G)S(H) \to S(G)S(H)→S(G) (or multi-valued map, S(H)→PS(G)S(H) \to \mathcal{P}S(G)S(H)→PS(G)). But this really depends on the chosen scheduler SSS.

So, from the distributed computing perspective, strictly speaking, the concept of fibration is not enough to capture patterns of synchrony: you need to specify the scheduler too. I don't know how this remark translates to biology, nor to category theory.

ps: there are other formalizations where the scheduler is stochastic. In that case, the executions you can lift from HHH can land in a zero-probability subset. So it can be tricky.

Although I am yet to understand fully, I think what you said as the "set of legal executions of a network", DeVille-Lerman in this paper described them as groupoid invariant virtual vector fields of a network (Definition 3.2.9 in DeVille-Lerman's paper). State of X(V)X(V)X(V) is a function S ⁣:V→XS \colon V \to XS:V→X, and the nthn_{th}nth​-time evolution of X(V)X(V)X(V) is given by the nthn_{th}nth​ composition of the function F ⁣:XV→XVF \colon X^{V} \to X^{V}F:XV→XV induced from the state functions ϕv\phi_{v}ϕv​.

Now, I am defining an anticipatory discrete network AX(V)AX(V)AX(V) on a finite set VVV as a set VVV, whose state functions are defined in a such a way that the t+1tht+1_{th}t+1th​ state of vvv is dependent on

  • ttht_{th}tth​ states of the nodes which influence vvv and the ttht_{th}tth​-time evolution of the nodes that vvv can influence.

I imagine the situation. as attached
anticipatorysystems.PNG

So, the (t+1)th(t+1)_{th}(t+1)th​ state of vvv is dependent on the ttht_{th}tth​ states of the blue nodes (which influences vvv) and the ttht_{th}tth​ time evolution of the states of the red nodes(which gets influenced by vvv).

In a way, I feel the above is more realistic that the usual discrete dynamical system. I may be mistaking something.

I am modelling anticipation in the following way:

State of vvv is not only dependent on the "just previous" state of the nodes that influence vvv but also on the "so far evolution of the states of the nodes that vvv can influence".

Hi!!

Recently, I have started working on an idea which combines two things in a single framework.

  • a notion of monoid labeled graph.
  • a notion of discrete dynamics.

First of all, thanks very much @John Baez for giving me so many helpful feedbacks on the initial version of the concepts which we discussed in direct messages.

The motivation behind this idea lies in the fact that "the state of a vertex vvv not only depends on the states of the neigbouring vertices but also on the types of influences those neighbouring vertices have on vvv". I called the notion labeled discrete network. Below, I am briefly describing the concept.

Let MMM be a monoid. An MMM-labeled discrete network X(V,M)X(V, M)X(V,M) consists of the following data:

  • a set VVV of nodes,
  • a set XXX of states,
  • A family of subsets {Nv⊆V}v∈V\lbrace N_{v} \subseteq V \rbrace_{v \in V}{Nv​⊆V}v∈V​, where for each v∈Vv \in Vv∈V, the elements of NvN_vNv​ are called the neighbours of vvv.
  • A function i ⁣:V×V→M∪{0}i \colon V \times V \to M \cup \lbrace 0 \rbracei:V×V→M∪{0}, called the labeling such that i(w,v)=0i(w,v)=0i(w,v)=0 if and only if w∉Nvw \notin N_{v}w∈/Nv​, where M∪{0}M \cup \lbrace 0 \rbraceM∪{0} is the unique monoid which extends MMM by the element 000 which is absorbing.
  • A family of functions {ϕv ⁣:(X×M)Nv→X}v∈V \lbrace \phi_{v} \colon (X \times M)^{N_{v}} \to X \rbrace_{v \in V}{ϕv​:(X×M)Nv​→X}v∈V​, such that for each ζ∈(X×M)Nv\zeta \in (X \times M)^{N_{v}}ζ∈(X×M)Nv​, we have pr2∘ζ=θv\rm{pr_2} \circ \zeta= \theta_{v}pr2​∘ζ=θv​, where for each v∈V,θv ⁣:Nv→Mv \in V, \theta_{v} \colon N_{v} \to Mv∈V,θv​:Nv​→M is given as w↦i(w,v)w \mapsto i(w,v)w↦i(w,v) and pr2\rm{pr}_{2}pr2​ is the projection map to MMM.

From the above data,

  • I have constructed a MMM-labled graph (G,ℓ)(G, \ell)(G,ℓ), which I called the underlying MMM-labeled graph of X(G,M)X(G, M)X(G,M)
  • I have constructed a presheaf F ⁣:BN→SetF \colon B \mathbb{N} \to \mathsf{Set}F:BN→Set, which I called the underlying discrete dynamical system of X(G,M)X(G, M)X(G,M) .

The reason for choosing a labeling monoid MMM over a `labeling set' because later I want to study the motifs in the underlying graph (G,ℓ)(G, \ell)(G,ℓ) of X(G,M)X(G, M)X(G,M).

I will be very glad to get feedbacks about my notion of labeled discrete network.

Thanks everyone in advance.

As I mentioned above: My main motivation for defining the noition of a labeled discrete network is to incorporate the notion of "types" on influences of the neighbouring vertices in the framework of a usual discrete network, where such influences are usually ignored. Hence, it is natural to expect, that if we ignore "such types of influences", then my "labeled discrete network" will become usual discrete network. How do you usually consider "asynchronous scheduler" in Computer science? Are there any standard techniques ?

This is a risky rabbit-hole. There is usually not many different ways to specify a synchronous scheduler, but there are many many different ways to specify an "asynchronous" scheduler, which depends on the underlying computation model.

Let me try to sketch a few variants:

  1. You can assume that at every time step ttt, only a subset Vt⊆VV_t \subseteq VVt​⊆V of nodes are "triggered". Hence, for two consecutive configurations

γt+1(v)={ϕv((γt+1(w),i(v,w))w∈Nv)if v∈Vtγt(v)if v∉Vt \gamma_{t+1}(v) = \begin{cases} \phi_v\big((\gamma_{t+1}(w), i(v,w))_{w \in N_v}\big) &\text{if } v \in V_t \\ \gamma_t(v) &\text{if } v \not\in V_t \end{cases}γt+1​(v)={ϕv​((γt+1​(w),i(v,w))w∈Nv​​)γt​(v)​if v∈Vt​if v∈Vt​​

If you allow any sequence (Vt)t≥0(V_t)_{t\ge 0}(Vt​)t≥0​, you stumble on trivial executions (e.g., no node is ever triggered), or unfair executions (e.g., some subset of nodes are only triggered finitely many times). So you may want to include "fairness" conditions: e.g., every node is triggered infinitely many times, or, every node is triggered uniformly at random, independently for every time step.

  1. Another variant is "asynchronous message-passing", probably the wildest. This one is further away from your settings. Imagine that, instead of globally defined time events, you have "send-message" or "receive-message" events. A node can send a message to a out-neighbor, or receive a message from a in-neighbor. The intertwining of these events defines an execution (aka a schedule). You may want to impose at least some restrictions on the ordering of these events: e.g. you cannot receive a message that has not be sent before. See for instance Lamport's "happen-before" relation. In this case, a scheduler is a set of "event posets".

I already mentioned that any Boolean network is a special case of a MMM-labeled discrete network X(V,M)X(V, M)X(V,M), when we choose X=BX= \mathbb{B}X=B and M={1}M=\lbrace 1 \rbraceM={1}. However, the main motivation for my definition of MMM-labeled discrete network lies in the study of dynamics of regulatory networks modeled as rig-labeled graphs. More precisely, a large class of examples of monoid-labeled discrete networks arise from rig- labeled graphs equipped with the data of schedulers, which may make my notion of monoid labeled discrete network as a good candidate for describing the discrete dynamics of regulatory networks.

First, I recall the notion of a rig (R,+,0,×,1)(R, +, 0, \times, 1)(R,+,0,×,1)-labled graph that @John Baez and I studied in this paper.

Definition:
Given a rig (R,+,0,×,1)(R, +, 0, \times, 1)(R,+,0,×,1), we define a RRR-labeled graph as pair (G,ℓ ⁣:E→R)(G, \ell \colon E \to R)(G,ℓ:E→R).

Next, I am defining a morphism of RRR-labeled graphs (which we have not explicitly defined in our paper).

Definition:
Given a rig RRR, a morphism ϕ ⁣:(G,ℓ)→(G′,ℓ′)\phi \colon (G, \ell) \to (G', \ell')ϕ:(G,ℓ)→(G′,ℓ′) is defined as an additive morphism of (R,+,0)(R,+,0)(R,+,0)-labeled graphs.

Next, I am introducing a notion of RRR-labeled graph equipped with a scheduler:

Definition:
Let (R,+,0,×,1)(R, +, 0, \times, 1)(R,+,0,×,1) be a rig. We define a RRR-labeled graph equipped with a scheduler as a pair ((G,ℓ),{ϕv ⁣:(X×R)Nv→X}v∈V) \big( (G, \ell), \lbrace \phi_{v} \colon (X \times R)^{N_{v}} \to X \rbrace_{v \in V} \big)((G,ℓ),{ϕv​:(X×R)Nv​→X}v∈V​), where Nv={w∈V ⁣:there is an edge  e∈E  such that  s(e)=w  and  t(e)=v}N_{v} = \lbrace w \in V \colon \text{there is an edge}\, \, e \in E \,\, \text{such that}\,\, s(e)=w \,\, \text{and} \,\, t(e)=v \rbraceNv​={w∈V:there is an edgee∈Esuch thats(e)=wandt(e)=v}. We say the RRR-labeled graph (G,ℓ)(G, \ell)(G,ℓ) is equipped with the scheduler {ϕv ⁣:(X×R)Nv→X}v∈V\lbrace \phi_{v} \colon (X \times R)^{N_{v}} \to X \rbrace_{v \in V} {ϕv​:(X×R)Nv​→X}v∈V​ .

This is the definition where I making an analogy with what Lerman-DeVille defined as network in their paper. I learnt the word scheduler first time from @Peva Blanchard Thanks!! Now, the justification of the word scheduler will probably come from the Lemma below (that I observed today)

Lemma:

For any RRR-labeled graph with scheduler ((G,ℓ ⁣:E→R),{ϕv ⁣:(X×R)Nv→X}v∈V)) \big( (G, \ell \colon E \to R), \lbrace \phi_{v} \colon (X \times R)^{N_{v}} \to X \rbrace_{v \in V} \big)\big)((G,ℓ:E→R),{ϕv​:(X×R)Nv​→X}v∈V​)), there is a (R,+,0)(R, +,0)(R,+,0)-labeled discrete network X(V,(R,+,0))X(V, (R, +,0))X(V,(R,+,0)).

The construction follows by observing that the map

i ⁣:V×V→(R,+,0)∪{0ˉ}i \colon V \times V \to (R,+,0) \cup \lbrace \bar{0}\rbracei:V×V→(R,+,0)∪{0ˉ} can be defined in the following way:

Let v1,v2∈Vv_1, v_2 \in Vv1​,v2​∈V. Then, if path (v1,v2)(v_1, v_2)(v1​,v2​) is non-empty, then define

i(v1,v2):=∑l(γ)γ∈path(v1,v2)i(v_1, v_2):= \sum l(\gamma)_{\gamma \in \text{path}(v_1,v_2)}i(v1​,v2​):=∑l(γ)γ∈path(v1​,v2​)​, otherwise 0ˉ\bar{0}0ˉ, if path (v1,v2)(v_1, v_2)(v1​,v2​) is empty.

Note that in the definition of ℓ(γ)\ell(\gamma)ℓ(γ), I have used the multiplicative monoid (R,×,1)(R, \times, 1)(R,×,1).

Thus (if I am not making any mistakes) now, we have a large class of examples of monoid labeled discrete networks arising from models of regulatory networks.

Now, using the additive morphisms, I think (yet to check everything in detail) there is a natural way to define a notion of morphism of RRR-labeled graphs with scheduler. We denote the corresponding category of RRR-labeled graphs with schedulers as Rsch−GphR_{sch}-\mathsf{Gph}Rsch​−Gph

Now, I conjecture the following:

Conjecture:
Given a rig RRR, there is a functor FR ⁣:Rsch−Gph→D(R,+,0))F_{R} \colon R_{sch}-\mathsf{Gph} \to D_{(R, +, 0))}FR​:Rsch​−Gph→D(R,+,0))​ which takes a RRR-labeled graph with scheduler to the associated (R,+,0)(R, +, 0)(R,+,0)-labeled discrete network.

Right: an LLL-labeled graph in our sense with vertex set VVV is different from a map V×V→N[L]V \times V \to \mathbb{N}[L]V×V→N[L] because in the latter there's no set of edges. For our kind of LLL-labeled graph there are non-identity morphisms that are the identity on vertices, but not on edges. But for maps V×V→N[L]V \times V \to \mathbb{N}[L]V×V→N[L], the most obvious sort of morphism is forced to be the identity if it's the identity on vertices.

This is a standard issue: e.g. there's a definition of Petri net where there's a set of arcs from any state to any transition, and another definition where there's just a number of them.

You get to decide which definition you want, depending on what you are doing with it.

It'll become more interesting if you prove some nontrivial theorems.

There are a bunch of trivial theorems, some of which take work to state. For example, you can construct a double category of 'open' dynamical networks of your sort. And you can construct a semantics for them: a double functor from them to a double category of open discrete dynamical systems. We've proved this kind of theorem so often I consider them trivial.

There are similar trivial theorems for open Petri nets with rates.

A slightly less trivial theorem for open Petri nets was constructing a 'black-boxing' functor that mapped them to relations that say what happens in a steady state.
A really interesting theorem would say something interesting about the dynamics of some class of dynamical networks of your sort.
For example, in the world of Petri nets with rates (≈\approx≈ reaction networks), the theorems about complex balanced equilibria are nontrivial and really interesting.

I am writing down what I am thinking:

Usual approach:

We usually first consider a Boolean network (or generalised version of them) as defined by @John Baez here #theory: applied category theory > Networks in Biology @ 💬 , and then this definition allows us to construct a directed graph. Now, the signs of the directed graph (+,−+,-+,−) comes from the Boolean logic. In most setting including Kauffmann, I think this kind of approach is taken.

The approach that I was talking for some days:

We start with a labeled graph, and we equip the nodes of the graph with the information of how their present states are depended on the previous states and the nature of influences of its neighbouring nodes. From this data, we can construct a discrete dynamical system. I think this approach is not much common. Closest existing work in this direction I could find are

  • Threshold Boolean network (For eg: Section 3 of this paper)
  • Coupled systems (For eg : Lerman-DeVille, Stewart, Golubitsky, Pivato). However, in their framework they described the coupling by unlabeled graph.

Even if I can prove some theorems telling when such dynamics has fixed point/ oscillation/ equilibrium/ etc., why these theorems would be relevant from the point of Biology?

Below, I am briefly writing down my understandings:

Regarding 1)

I was trying to understand how a cell processes information coming in the form of biochemical signaling molecules known as ligands and react to them. A cell recieves extracellular and intracellular signals and react to these signals by producing specific protiens and /or RNA-molecule which perform certain precise functions. For example, an intracellular signal can tell the cell that "DNA is damaged and it needs a repair". Then, as a response to the said intracellular signal, the cell produces protiens and/or RNA molecules that repairs DNA. On the other hand, an extracellular signal can come from outside the cell which asks the cell to produce certain proteins and/or RNA molecules for performing certain specific tasks. Cells execute these tasks with precision. For example, Epidermal growth Factor (EGF) is an extracellular signal that asks the cell to produce protiens resposible for cell proliferation. Below, I am trying to give a brief overview of cellular response to signals, which to me is a particular instance of my question "how molecular interactions give rise to cellular behaviour".

Step 1:
Ligands bind with specific receptors present in the cell. Note that for the extra cellular signals the receptors usually lie in the cell membrane , but for intracelular signals the receptors usually lie inside the cell (For eg: Steroid hormone receptors).

Step 2:
The binding of signalling molecules with the receptors cause changes in the configuration of the receptors, which trigger chains of biochemical events known as signalling pathways. When different signalling pathways interact (crosstalk) we get a network called signal tranduction network. The main function of this network is to relay the signal (often via amplifying/damping) by activating various protiens (eg: via phosphorylation) and producing second messengers (eg: realising calcium ions in the cytosol) and finally activating special kinds of protiens called transcription factors (For example, P53 is a transcription factor for activating genes producing protiens responsible for tumour supression), which are resposible for regulating genes in the DNA to produce specific protiens and/or RNA molecules that will perform the biological task asked by the signalling molecules.

Step 3:

When a transctiption factor gets activated by a signal transduction network, it regulates (often stimulate/ repress) the activity of genes which produce either non-coding RNA molecules , or messenger RNA containing the copy of information present in the genes. This process of copying the gene encoded message into RNA molecules is called transcription. The non-coded RNA molecules have important biological roles on their own, but they do not get converted to protiens. However, messanger RNA molecules (whose function is mostly to copy the gene instruction) can enter ribosomes for protien synthesis via a process called translation. Often, the produced protien is another transcription factor for some other gene/s then, it regulate other genes which may produce protiens and or RNA molecules. Again, the produced protiens could be transcription factors for some others genes and so on. This results in a network called transcrioption networks (often called gene regulatory network) which regulate gene expressions. Expression of a gene is the amount of protien produced by the gene at a given time.

So, now, my initial question "how molecular intereactions give rise to cellular function" took a bit precise form : How signalling molecules produce gene expressions? Thus, the answer lies in Step 1-3.

Regarding 2)
According to Uri Alon, transcription network can be modeled as directed signed graphs whose edges are labeled by +++ and −-−. An edge a→+ba \xrightarrow{+} ba+​b means the product of gene aaa is a transcription factor that can stimulate the rate at which the gene bbb is transcribing. Similarly, an edge a→−ba \xrightarrow{-} ba−​b means the product of gene aaa is a transcription factor that can represss the rate at which the gene bbb is transcribing. This rate depends on both he concentration of the transcription factors (produced by aaa) and also the chemical affinity for the binding of the transcription factor to the promoter of the gene bbb.

Now, the arrows in the transcription network always vary due to mutation in the DNA (which has been experimentally proved to be a random event). According to Uri Alon, network motifs are the patterns that survived evolution, that is random mutations. According to Uri Alon, a way to identify such motifs is by identifying patterns in gene regulatory networks that ouccur much more often that in randomized networks having same number of nodes and arrows. For example, negative autoregulation (walking negative feedback loop), postive auto regulations (walking positive feedback loop), feedforward loops, etc are example of such motifs.

Next, big question: if these patterns have been selected via natural selection, then they must serve some purposes. For example, Uri Alon demonstrated the purpose of a negative autoregulation by showing that their dynamics (rate of concentrations of the produced gene regulated by transcription factors and the binding strength of the transcription factor with the promoter of the target gene) are very special (via the Hill equation), and play crucial roles with respect to "achieving and maintaining steady states of the concentration of the protiens produced by the genes activated by transcription factors".

A question in this regard:
I agree that there are patterns in gene regulatory networks chosen by natural selection. Biologists found some and showed their significance in terms of individual dynamics (at least the portion I read so far). However, it is not clear to me how the dynamics of these motifs would behave when they are placed in a sufficient number inside a very large gene regulatory network responsible for the regulations of certain genes.

I felt signal transduction networks are more like the kind of networks treated in the Chapter 5 of this and gene regulatory networks are more like Z/2\mathbb{Z}/2Z/2-labeled graphs. If we have to understand Step 1-3 in a single framework, then it may be the case that we may need to conisder/develop a more general framework that encompasses both a monoid labeled graphs and signal flow graph within the same framework.

However, statistical abundance by itself does not imply that these circuits are fundamental bricks of biological systems. Fundamental circuits of biological networks can be underrepresented and appear only once in the network, yet they can have overwhelming importance for the functioning of the cell.

Motifs are good for finding basic building blocks that are statistically repeated ubiquitously. However, the functional significance of these network motifs has been debated, and results indicate that the link between motif and function does not exist (Ingram et al., 2006; Payne and Wagner, 2015; Macıa et al., 2009; Ahnert and Fink, 2016). Indeed, except for the FAN motif, other motifs found by Alon and coworkers (Milo et al., 2002) do not lead to synchronization or other clear functional roles. Thus, the mere statistical significance of the network motif may not confer a definitive functionality within the cell machinery. (p. 332)

The chapter (17) then goes on to give statistical analyses of motif abundance. Naturally, fibrations appear to them as much more important.

Yes, chap. 21 for that:

One of the main advantages of using symmetries to characterize dynamics is that the synchrony patterns that we predict are combinatorial/topological properties of the network, thus largely independent of the explicit form of the dynamical equations. Therefore, we do not need to specify the equations that describe the dynamics of the system—be it a neural system, a genetic network, or any other physical, chemical, or biological system—beyond the general form from Definition 3.10, as long as the ODEs are admissible for the graph. We, therefore, derive all our results for a general type of dynamics, which can then be specialized to particular systems. However, particular systems are characterized by a large number of parameters and most of them are required to be the same for symmetry to exist. Unfortunately, this ‘uniformity condition’ is never strictly realized in biology. How is the coherent synchronization necessary for life to emerge?

We treat this question below. We first elaborate on an ideal model of gene expression that predicts perfect synchrony. Then we show that the conditions for this model are not realized in biology due to the broad parameter space of interactions among genes, proteins, and small molecules. We discuss how to reconcile this result with the observed (quasi-perfect) synchrony in real systems.

  • They define a state of a gene vvv as v(t)∈Rv(t) \in \mathbb{R}v(t)∈R, representing the expression level of the gene ggg at time t∈Rt \in \mathbb{R}t∈R.
  • From the above graph GGG, they construct a minimal fibration ϕ ⁣:G→B\phi \colon G \to Bϕ:G→B. The minimal fibration of a graph is unique upto isomorphism and there are various algorithms to construct such a minimal base (For example, see section 4 of Boldi-Vigna).
  • Now, from the local in-isomorphism property of graph fibration, the genes in the fibre have isomorphic in-put history. This is the motivation for them to claim that if gene vvv and www are in the same fibre then, vvv and www are expected to synchronize that is v(t)=w(t)v(t)=w(t)v(t)=w(t) for all t∈Rt \in \mathbb{R}t∈R i.e the expression level of the gene vvv and www will always be same.
  • Now, they took the De-Ville's approach to define the total phase space of the graph GGG as PG=R∣V∣PG= \mathbb{R}^{|V|}PG=R∣V∣.
  • As shown by De-Ville Lerman, associated to the minimal fibration ϕ ⁣:G→B\phi \colon G \to Bϕ:G→B, using the universal property of the product we get a map between total phase spaces of the graphs i.e Pϕ ⁣:PB→PGP \phi \colon PB \to PGPϕ:PB→PG, where PG=R∣V∣PG= \mathbb{R}^{|V|}PG=R∣V∣ and PBPBPB is also defined similarly.
  • Since a minimal fibration is surjective, they could use the De-Ville Lerman's result to say PϕP \phiPϕ is an embedding of manifolds and the image of PϕP \phiPϕ is a polydiagonal along the fibres i.e if (v1(t),v2(t),⋯vn(t))∈Rn:=∣v∣(v_1(t), v_2(t), \cdots v_{n}(t)) \in \mathbb{R}^{n:=|v|}(v1​(t),v2​(t),⋯vn​(t))∈Rn:=∣v∣ is a point in the image of PϕP \phiPϕ, then whenever vi,vjv_i, v_jvi​,vj​ are in the same fibre of ϕ\phiϕ, we have vi(t)=vj(t)v_i(t)=v_j(t)vi​(t)=vj​(t). This proved their claim mathematically that whenever two genes have same-input history they have the same expressions all the time.

Thus, yes, I am overall convinced that they have used the DeVille-Lerman's results correctly to talk about "their kind" of synchrony.

However, I feel the more important questions are the following:

  • 1) If we consider the standard continuous dynamics like Hills equation (as considered by Uri Alon and many others), will the above said synchrony be reflected in the the said dynamics ?
  • 2) Often they argued on reducing the network size by applying minimal fibrations. Are these "standard dynamics" preserved under the minimal fibrations?

As argued in the Chapter 21.6 in that Big Book, these answers are are turned out to be false. Dynamical systems only shows such synchrony when some "very heavy" assumptions are made as argue in the Chapter 21.5 of that Big Book.

Then, what is the solution to this problem? Did that Big book gave a concrete answer?

I think no!! Although they talked about broken symmetry, they have clearly mentioned "this kind of symmetry breaking" is different from "what they have discussed in Chapter 18 (which is analogous to electronic circuit)". They did talk about some possible ways (Page 422 of the Big Book) to address this issue especially via developing a "pseuodofibration" theory, but it was clear that such a theory does not exists at least now. In fact they are welcoming the readers to develop such a theory.

Now, my thoughts:

Thus, like motifs-anti-motifs, I am realising their approach may also be far from complete. However, still from the number of succesful studies done in two approaches, I think the concept of motifs and antimotifs may be more well-studied theory at the current stage. However, it is also possible that I may be misunderstading some aspects and may be I will understand my mistakes after some days .

Hi!

During the month of July-August this year, in this thread we discussed several things on various aspects of networks in Biological systems. Thanks very much to everyone who participated in this thread. It helped me to learn many many things. After August, for some period I was involved with something else (I was learning Topological Data Analysis especially application of persistence homology in Biological data, eg: FMRI data).

Among several other things we discussed during July-August, we spent a considerable amount of time in Boolean dynamics/more generally discrete dynamics of Biological networks, eg: gene regulatory networks. For the last 2 months, I developed an interest in understanding how dynamics of gene regulatory networks interacts with the dynamics of metabolic networks and signalling networks despite their time scale differences.

I want to model a gene regulatory network as a Boolean network so that its dynamics can interact with the dynamics of other networks. Boolean models are especially useful when the network size is large because large scale differential equations based models of biological systems are often hard to construct due to the presence of large number of unknown but essential kinetic parametres. Before moving to the investigation of how the dynamics of Boolean model of gene regulatory networks interacts with the dynamics of metabolic networks and signalling networks, I was trying to understand the interaction of the dynamics of nnn-number of Boolean networks in a formal way.

As of now, I was unable to find an immediate use of category theory in my framework, but hopefully, I will find eventually.

Below I am briefly describing my framework:

I considered the definition of the Boolean network as prescribed by @John Baez earlier in this thread, which I am recalling below:

By a Boolean network, I meant a tuple B=(V,(Nv,ϕv)v∈V)B= \big(V, (N_{v}, \phi_{v})_{v \in V} \big)B=(V,(Nv​,ϕv​)v∈V​), where

  • VVV is a finite set,
  • a set Nv⊆VN_{v} \subseteq VNv​⊆V for each v∈Vv \in Vv∈V,
  • a function ϕv ⁣:BNv→B\phi_{v} \colon \mathbb{B}^{N_{v}} \to \mathbb{B}ϕv​:BNv​→B for each v∈Vv \in Vv∈V.

This Boolean network BBB naturally generates a dynamics

  • TB ⁣:BV→BVT_{B} \colon \mathbb{B}^{V} \to \mathbb{B}^{V}TB​:BV→BV defined as (ζ ⁣:V→B)↦TB(ζ) ⁣:V→B,v↦ϕv(ζ∣Nv)(\zeta \colon V \to \mathbb{B}) \mapsto T_{B}(\zeta) \colon V \to \mathbb{B}, v \mapsto \phi_{v}(\zeta|_{N_{v}})(ζ:V→B)↦TB​(ζ):V→B,v↦ϕv​(ζ∣Nv​​) for all v∈Vv \in Vv∈V and ζ∈BV\zeta \in \mathbb{B}^{V}ζ∈BV.

By definition, the dynamics TBT_{B}TB​ is synchronous and deterministic.

Now, I want to investigate the following four questions:

  • (1) What does it mean to say a pair of Boolean network is coupled?
  • (2) How to describe the dynamics of the coupled pair of Boolean networks?
  • (3) How to quantify the difference between the dynamics of the coupled pair of Boolean networks and the dynamics of the uncoupled pair? Can we talk about emergent effect in this aspect?
  • (4) How to generalise the above ideas to a notion of coupled system of nnn number of Boolean networks for any narural number n∈Nn \in \mathbb{N}n∈N?

(1) What does it mean to say a pair of Boolean network is coupled?

This is interesting. Have you considered trying to define "open boolean networks"?

Thank you. In a way, when I considered an action of a Boolean network on another, then the Boolean network is interacting with another Boolean network, and technically it is an open Boolean network.

Now, if I want to model an open Boolean network as a structured cospan X→iB←oYX \xrightarrow{i} B \xleftarrow{o} YXi​Bo​Y, then horizontal composition of structured cospans (via pushout construction) is supposed to model the interaction. However, I think when we compose X→iB←oYX \xrightarrow{i} B \xleftarrow{o} YXi​Bo​Y and Y→iB′←oZY \xrightarrow{i} B' \xleftarrow{o} ZYi​B′o​Z, we need to identify some elements of VVV and V′V'V′, the set of nodes in BBB and B′B'B′, respectively, which may be a little restrictive from the point of Biology. For example, if we model a metabolic network MMM as a Boolean network BM=(VM,(Nr,ϕr)r∈VM)B_{M}= (V_{M}, (N_{r}, \phi_{r})_{r \in V_{M}})BM​=(VM​,(Nr​,ϕr​)r∈VM​​), where

  • VMV_{M}VM​ is the set of all reactions rrr in the metabolic network MMM,
  • NrN_{r}Nr​ is the set of reactions in MMM whose ttht_{th}tth​ states determines the (t+1)th(t+1)_{th}(t+1)th​-state of the reaction rrr, and ϕr ⁣:BNr→B\phi_{r} \colon \mathbb{B}^{N_{r}} \to \mathbb{B}ϕr​:BNr​→B, says "how it does".

When a reaction rrr has the satate 111, we can think of it as an active reaction because may be the enzyme concentration for the reaction rrr is good enough for the reaction to happen in realistic time-scale. When the enzyme concentration is not good enough for the reaction to happen, then I am considering the state of the reaction as 000. However, we can also think, that when the substrates (inputs) for a reaction has not been formed yet, the reaction is in the inactive state. Hence, it may be possible that a reaction rrr depends on the availablilty of the substrates s1,s2,⋯ ,sns_1, s_2, \cdots, s_{n}s1​,s2​,⋯,sn​, produced as metabolites(output of reactions) of reactions r1,r2,⋯ ,rmr_1, r_{2}, \cdots, r_{m}r1​,r2​,⋯,rm​ in MMM. Thus, the concept of NrN_{r}Nr​ and ϕr\phi_{r}ϕr​ makes sense in biological context. Now, many of the produced metabolites behave as signalling molecules which in turn activate or inhibit several transcription factors, hence, genes in the gene regulatory network. Thus, the states of the genes in the gene regulatory network depends on the metabolites produced by some reactions in the metabolic network, and hence, on the states of those reactions. From this consideration, I feel "identification of nodes when considering open Boolean network as a structured cospan" is a bit restrictive than the definition I constructed in my previous post i.e the action of a Boolean network on another. To me, intituively , it feels more like an action of one network on another.

Modularity in Biological Systems:

There had been several works which discuss modularity in biological systems. For example,

  • Network motifs: Uri Alon An Introduction to Systems Biology, John J Tyson et al. Functional Motifs in Biochemical Reaction Networks and others have tried to undertand the global dynamics of gene regulatory networks in terms of the dynamics of the network motifs-statistically over represented patterns in the graphical representation of gene regulatory networks.
  • Strongly Connected Components of the wiring diagram of Boolean networks: Reinhard Laubenbacher et al. Modularity of biological systems: a link between structure and function worked on controlling the global dynamics of a synchronous Boolean network by controlling the modules Modular control of Boolean network models.
  • Fibres of graph fibration: Stewart et al Symmetries of Living Systems: Symmetry Fibrations and Synchronization in Biological Networks charactrises synchrony modules in gene regulatory networks (genes whose dynamics are same) via fibres of graph fibrations using Lerman et al.'s results in Modular dynamical systems on networks.

There are probably many other kinds of already explored notion of modularity of biological systems that exist in the literature. Instead of trying to list all of them, I want to state my point.

From my experiance, a main focus of Applied Category Theory has been in the formal study of systems via compositionality i.e by

  • decomposing a system into a collection of subsystems
  • study the subsystems
  • combine the studies of the subsystems to say something meaningful about the system itself.

Usually, we model the systems (more correctly open systems i.e. the systems which interacts with other systems) as certain kinds of morphisms within a categorical gadget (a category, higher category, operads, etc.) and then use the compositional law of the categorical gadget to combine open systems into a bigger system. Now, there are works in Applied Category Theory which model biochemical reaction networks, gene regulatory networks etc. as certain morphisms within categorical gadgets, which gave us compositional theories of biochemical reaction networks, gene regulatory networks etc. Also, there are works to study their dynamics compositionally via functorial semantics.

However, unlike the ones I mentioned above ( Network motifs, Strongly Connected Components of the wiring diagram of Boolean networks, Fibres of graph fibration), I feel the kind of modules discussed in ACT is too general. For example,

  • network motifs are characteised by the fact that they are statistically over represented patterns in the graphical representation of gene regulatory networks and they have been shown to play crucial role in the overal dynamics of gene regulatory network,
  • strongly connected components in the wiring diagram of Boolean network has a precise graph theoretic meaning and they have been shown to play a crucial role in controlling the dynamics of Boolean networks.
  • Fibrational symmetry also has similar precise mathematical menaing and has been shown to play crucial biological roles in identifying synchronous entities.

Now, I think the modules provided by ACT (if I think only in terms of existing compositionality theorems in ACT) are arbitrary morphisms of some categorical gadgets (structured cospans in a symmetric monoidal double category, decorated cospans in a symmetric monoidal category , etc.) However, I am not able to guess how these kinds of modularity can actually help in the modular study of bioligical systems like the way the other notions (mentioned) above have done.

I am interested in the study of already present modularity (I am assuming it) in biological systems using Applied Category Theory machineries. In that case, do we need to come up with notions of distinguished morphisms in the categorical gadgets such that

  1. semantics (for eg: dynamics) of these distinguished morphisms play cricucial roles biologically and
  2. every morphism in the categorical gadget can be expressed in terms of compositonal laws of those distinguished morphisms and some possibly special morphisms.
    ?

It is also possible that I am misunderstanding certain things.

More generally, how existing compositionality theorems in ACT can be used in the study of already present modularity in biological systems ? How can we decompose a biological system using ACT machinaries into modules such that the interconnected semantics of these modules can be shown to be crucial in decoding the semantic of the whole biological system? Of course, a positive answer to the above two questions will also give us notions of subsystems which are not considered as modules because the knowledge of their semantics can be shown to play very little role in the overall semantics of the whole biological system.
